question: Define and compare kinetic energy, potential energy, chemical energy, and heat.

answerLines.raw: Kinetic energy: the energy of motion
answerLines.text: Kinetic energy: the energy of motion

answerLines.raw: Potential energy: Stored energy, capable of becoming kinetic energy
answerLines.text: Potential energy: Stored energy, capable of becoming kinetic energy

answerLines.raw: Chemical energy: (potential energy) in the form of complex sugar molecules with covalent C—H bonds
answerLines.text: Chemical energy: (potential energy) in the form of complex sugar molecules with covalent C—H bonds

answerLines.raw: Heat: (kinetic) A measure of the random motion of molecules
answerLines.text: Heat: (kinetic) A measure of the random motion of molecules

question: Define the two laws of thermodynamics and explain how they relate to biological systems.

answerLines.raw: First: Total amount of energy in the universe is constant, cannot be created or destroyed
answerLines.text: First: Total amount of energy in the universe is constant, cannot be created or destroyed

answerLines.raw: Second: Disorder in a closed system is continuously increasing
answerLines.text: Second: Disorder in a closed system is continuously increasing

question: Define entropy

answerLines.raw: A measure of the degree of disorder of a system
answerLines.text: A measure of the degree of disorder of a system

question: Define and compare endergonic and exergonic reactions.

answerLines.raw: Endergonic: products contain more energy than reactants, and needs an outside source of energy. Not spontaneous.
answerLines.text: Endergonic: products contain more energy than reactants, and needs an outside source of energy. Not spontaneous.

answerLines.raw: Exergonic: products have less free energy than reactant, tends to be spontaneous
answerLines.text: Exergonic: products have less free energy than reactant, tends to be spontaneous

question: Explain how cells use cellular respiration and energy coupling to survive.

answerLines.raw: Respiration generates ATP, which is then coupled, or transferred, to power all the cellular processes
answerLines.text: Respiration generates ATP, which is then coupled, or transferred, to power all the cellular processes

answerLines.raw: Endergonic reactions in cells are typically tied to the reaction of the terminal phosphate of ATP breaking off
answerLines.text: Endergonic reactions in cells are typically tied to the reaction of the terminal phosphate of ATP breaking off

question: Define activation energy

answerLines.raw: The energy a molecule must acquire to undergo a specific chemical reaction, to destabilize chemical bonds (usu. Heat, sunlight, or ATP)
answerLines.text: The energy a molecule must acquire to undergo a specific chemical reaction, to destabilize chemical bonds (usu. Heat, sunlight, or ATP)

question: Explain how catalysts speed up chemical reactions.

answerLines.raw: They lower the activation energy
answerLines.text: They lower the activation energy

question: Differentiate between an enzyme’s active site and its binding site.

answerLines.raw: Active site: the site on the enzyme where a substrate binds
answerLines.text: Active site: the site on the enzyme where a substrate binds

answerLines.raw: Binding site: the site on a substrate/reactant that binds to an enzyme
answerLines.text: Binding site: the site on a substrate/reactant that binds to an enzyme

question: Distinguish between a chemical reaction and a biochemical pathway

answerLines.raw: Chemical reactions are the basic units of change, while a biochemical pathway is the assembly line that starts with reactants and and after a series of chemical reactions involving enzymes, results in a product. Example: glycolysis
answerLines.text: Chemical reactions are the basic units of change, while a biochemical pathway is the assembly line that starts with reactants and and after a series of chemical reactions involving enzymes, results in a product. Example: glycolysis

question: Explain the influence of temperature on an enzyme-catalyzed reaction

answerLines.raw: Enzymes have an optimal temperature where there activity peaks. Low temperatures slow down reactions, too high temperatures permanently damage the enzymes.
answerLines.text: Enzymes have an optimal temperature where there activity peaks. Low temperatures slow down reactions, too high temperatures permanently damage the enzymes.

question: Explain how competitive and noncompetitive inhibitors alter an enzyme’s activity through feedback inhibition.

answerLines.raw: Competitive inhibitors: the product binds ot the same active site as the substrate
answerLines.text: Competitive inhibitors: the product binds ot the same active site as the substrate

answerLines.raw: Noncompetitive inhibitors: product binds to a different allosteric site, changing the shape of the enzyme so the other substrate can’t bind.
answerLines.text: Noncompetitive inhibitors: product binds to a different allosteric site, changing the shape of the enzyme so the other substrate can’t bind.

question: Explain how certain drugs, pesticides, and poisons can affect enzymes.

answerLines.raw: These things are designed to be enzyme inhibitors, to affect an essential biochemical pathway
answerLines.text: These things are designed to be enzyme inhibitors, to affect an essential biochemical pathway

question: Explain how the chain of three phosphate groups in ATP stores potential energy

answerLines.raw: Stored in the phosphate groups, which are forced to cluster together
answerLines.text: Stored in the phosphate groups, which are forced to cluster together

question: Name the three layers of the leaf through which light must pass to reach chloroplasts.

answerLines.raw: Cuticle: waxy, protective, watertight first layer
answerLines.text: Cuticle: waxy, protective, watertight first layer

answerLines.raw: Epidermis: 1-cell thick “skin” of the leaf, controls how gas/water enters the leaf
answerLines.text: Epidermis: 1-cell thick “skin” of the leaf, controls how gas/water enters the leaf

answerLines.raw: Mesophyll: fills the leaf interior, contains chloroplasts
answerLines.text: Mesophyll: fills the leaf interior, contains chloroplasts

question: Summarize the photosynthetic events that occur within the chloroplast.

answerLines.raw: Step one: sunlight strikes the surface membrane of thylakoids
answerLines.text: Step one: sunlight strikes the surface membrane of thylakoids

answerLines.raw: Step 2: wherever a photon strikes the photosystem, since chlorophyll molecule will be in position to receive it
answerLines.text: Step 2: wherever a photon strikes the photosystem, since chlorophyll molecule will be in position to receive it

answerLines.raw: Step 3: chlorophyll molecules excited. Photons energy absorbed by chlorophyll, boosting its electrons and passing excitation to neighbors
answerLines.text: Step 3: chlorophyll molecules excited. Photons energy absorbed by chlorophyll, boosting its electrons and passing excitation to neighbors

answerLines.raw: Step 4: Energy settles into a key chlorophyll touching a membrane protein, which transfers the energy to an acceptor molecule
answerLines.text: Step 4: Energy settles into a key chlorophyll touching a membrane protein, which transfers the energy to an acceptor molecule

question: Describe what a photon is made of, and state in what way its energy is related to its wavelength.

answerLines.raw: Photons are light energy. They are both particles and waves.
answerLines.text: Photons are light energy. They are both particles and waves.

answerLines.raw: Shorter wavelength = high energy, longer wavelength = lower energy
answerLines.text: Shorter wavelength = high energy, longer wavelength = lower energy

question: Identify which color(s) of light are NOT absorbed by the pigment chlorophyll.

answerLines.raw: Green
answerLines.text: Green

question: List and describe the five stages of the light dependent reactions.

answerLines.raw: Light Absorption and Water Splitting (oxidation) (Photosystem II)
answerLines.text: Light Absorption and Water Splitting (oxidation) (Photosystem II)

answerLines.raw: Electron Transport Chain
answerLines.text: Electron Transport Chain

answerLines.raw: Light Re-energization (Photosystem I) more solar energy added
answerLines.text: Light Re-energization (Photosystem I) more solar energy added

answerLines.raw: NADPH Formation: H Protons transferred to NADP+ to make NADPH
answerLines.text: NADPH Formation: H Protons transferred to NADP+ to make NADPH

answerLines.raw: ATP Synthesis (Chemiosmosis)  H+ ions (protons) used to power concentration gradient for thylakoid membrane’s electrical charge
answerLines.text: ATP Synthesis (Chemiosmosis)  H+ ions (protons) used to power concentration gradient for thylakoid membrane’s electrical charge

question: Differentiate reaction center chlorophyll molecules from other photosystem chlorophyll molecules.

answerLines.raw: Reaction center chlorophyll molecules come in pairs, and convert light energy into chemical energy (redox reaction) to be sent to a primary electron acceptor
answerLines.text: Reaction center chlorophyll molecules come in pairs, and convert light energy into chemical energy (redox reaction) to be sent to a primary electron acceptor

answerLines.raw: Other photosystem molecules function to harvest light energy and pass on excited electrons to neighbors
answerLines.text: Other photosystem molecules function to harvest light energy and pass on excited electrons to neighbors

question: Describe the function of the electron transport system in noncyclic photophosphorylation.

answerLines.raw: To establish the proton gradient, connect the photosystems, and contribute to NADPH production
answerLines.text: To establish the proton gradient, connect the photosystems, and contribute to NADPH production

question: Explain why the Calvin cycle required NADPH as well as ATP.

answerLines.raw: ATP and NADPH are both needed to “fix” carbon dioxide into carbohydrate molecules (sugar)
answerLines.text: ATP and NADPH are both needed to “fix” carbon dioxide into carbohydrate molecules (sugar)

answerLines.raw: NADPH supplies the electrons for reducing CO2
answerLines.text: NADPH supplies the electrons for reducing CO2

answerLines.raw: ATP provides the chemical energy to power the reaction
answerLines.text: ATP provides the chemical energy to power the reaction

question: Explain why continuously photosynthesizing cells don’t run out of ADP to use in making ATP.

answerLines.raw: The processes that use ATP (Calvin Cycle) provides the ADP for the light-dependent reactions
answerLines.text: The processes that use ATP (Calvin Cycle) provides the ADP for the light-dependent reactions

question: Distinguish between C3 and C4 photosynthesis.

answerLines.raw: C3: used by most plants in hot and dry environments, initiates photorespiration after the stomata close to conserve water. Built up O2 is incorporated into the Calvin cycle instead of CO2. Light reactions slow down and cease
answerLines.text: C3: used by most plants in hot and dry environments, initiates photorespiration after the stomata close to conserve water. Built up O2 is incorporated into the Calvin cycle instead of CO2. Light reactions slow down and cease

answerLines.raw: C4: uses partitioned bundle sheath cells to contain built-up CO2, which is where the Calvin Cycle proceeds using its usual CO2. It keeps the Calvin Cycle separate from the mesophyll cell.
answerLines.text: C4: uses partitioned bundle sheath cells to contain built-up CO2, which is where the Calvin Cycle proceeds using its usual CO2. It keeps the Calvin Cycle separate from the mesophyll cell.

question: Compare the processes and locations of cellular respiration and photosynthesis.

answerLines.raw: Cellular respiration inputs glucose and oxygen to make carbon dioxide and water, while photosynthesis does the opposite: converts CO2 and water into glucose and oxygen
answerLines.text: Cellular respiration inputs glucose and oxygen to make carbon dioxide and water, while photosynthesis does the opposite: converts CO2 and water into glucose and oxygen

answerLines.raw: Cellular respiration happens in the cytoplasm of the cell and the mitochondria
answerLines.text: Cellular respiration happens in the cytoplasm of the cell and the mitochondria

answerLines.raw: Photosynthesis happens in the thylakoids of chloroplasts.
answerLines.text: Photosynthesis happens in the thylakoids of chloroplasts.

question: Provide the overall chemical equation for cellular respiration.

answerLines.raw: C6H12O6 (glucose) + 6O2 (oxygen = 6CO2 + 6H20
answerLines.text: C6H12O6 (glucose) + 6O2 (oxygen = 6CO2 + 6H20

question: State how many molecules of ATP are made from a glucose molecule during glycolysis.

answerLines.raw: 4 ATP molecules, 2 net gain
answerLines.text: 4 ATP molecules, 2 net gain

question: Describe the enzyme that removes CO2 from pyruvate and the metabolic significance of doing so.

answerLines.raw: Pyruvate Dehydrogenase Complex facilitates oxidation of the two-carbon acetyl group, and the high-energy electrons released are captured by NAD+, reducing it to NADH
answerLines.text: Pyruvate Dehydrogenase Complex facilitates oxidation of the two-carbon acetyl group, and the high-energy electrons released are captured by NAD+, reducing it to NADH

question: Identify the substrates for the nine-reaction Krebs cycle and the overall products.

answerLines.raw: Krebs input: Acetyl-CoA, NAD+ and FAD, oxaloacetate
answerLines.text: Krebs input: Acetyl-CoA, NAD+ and FAD, oxaloacetate

answerLines.raw: Krebs output: NADH, CO2, ATP, FADH
answerLines.text: Krebs output: NADH, CO2, ATP, FADH

question: Explain how redox reactions are used in cellular respiration.

answerLines.raw: Oxidation-reduction reactions: oxidation is the loss of an electron, reduction is the gaining of an electron
answerLines.text: Oxidation-reduction reactions: oxidation is the loss of an electron, reduction is the gaining of an electron

answerLines.raw: Redox reactions transfer electrons from highly reduced glucose molecules to highly oxidized oxygen molecules, whose energy transfers are captured in ATP
answerLines.text: Redox reactions transfer electrons from highly reduced glucose molecules to highly oxidized oxygen molecules, whose energy transfers are captured in ATP

question: Describe the general roles of dehydrogenase, NADH, and the electron transport chain in cellular respiration.

answerLines.raw: Dehydrogenase enzymes perform the redox reaction: removes hydrogen ions (oxidation) and gives electrons (reduces) to NAD+ and FAD to make NADH and FADH
answerLines.text: Dehydrogenase enzymes perform the redox reaction: removes hydrogen ions (oxidation) and gives electrons (reduces) to NAD+ and FAD to make NADH and FADH

answerLines.raw: NADH works as an electron carrier along the electron transport chain
answerLines.text: NADH works as an electron carrier along the electron transport chain

answerLines.raw: The electron transport chain: Its primary role is not to make ATP directly, but to use the energy from electron transfers to build the proton gradient that ultimately powers ATP synthesis
answerLines.text: The electron transport chain: Its primary role is not to make ATP directly, but to use the energy from electron transfers to build the proton gradient that ultimately powers ATP synthesis

question: Compare the reactants, products, and energy yield of the three stages of cellular respiration.

answerLines.raw: Glycolysis: glucose yields 2 pyruvate, H20 and H+ ions
answerLines.text: Glycolysis: glucose yields 2 pyruvate, H20 and H+ ions

answerLines.raw: Krebs/Citric Acid cycle: starts with pyruvate, yields Co2, ATP, FADH and NADH
answerLines.text: Krebs/Citric Acid cycle: starts with pyruvate, yields Co2, ATP, FADH and NADH

answerLines.raw: Electron Transport chain: starts with H+, through chemiosmosis yields  NADH and FADH, yields 32 ATP and H2o
answerLines.text: Electron Transport chain: starts with H+, through chemiosmosis yields  NADH and FADH, yields 32 ATP and H2o

question: Discuss how many ATP molecules are harvested in aerobic versus anaerobic respiration.

answerLines.raw: Anaerobic respiration (glycolysis in the cytoplasm) yields 4 ATP (2 net)
answerLines.text: Anaerobic respiration (glycolysis in the cytoplasm) yields 4 ATP (2 net)

answerLines.raw: Aerobic respiration in the mitochondria yields 32 ATP
answerLines.text: Aerobic respiration in the mitochondria yields 32 ATP

question: Describe the special function of brown fat.

answerLines.raw: The special function of brown fat is to generate heat without shivering, a process known as non-shivering thermogenesis
answerLines.text: The special function of brown fat is to generate heat without shivering, a process known as non-shivering thermogenesis

question: Compare the reactants, products, and energy yield of alcohol and lactic acid fermentation.

answerLines.raw: Alcohol: Glucose and Pyruvate yields Co2 and acetyldehyde
answerLines.text: Alcohol: Glucose and Pyruvate yields Co2 and acetyldehyde

answerLines.raw: Lactic Acid: Converts pyruvate into lactic acid
answerLines.text: Lactic Acid: Converts pyruvate into lactic acid

answerLines.raw: Both have the purpose of oxidizing NADH to NAD+
answerLines.text: Both have the purpose of oxidizing NADH to NAD+

question: Distinguish between obligate anaerobes and facultative anaerobes.

answerLines.raw: Obligate anaerobes find oxygen toxic while facultative anaerobes like E. coli use aerobic respiration foremost and can switch due to lack of oxygen
answerLines.text: Obligate anaerobes find oxygen toxic while facultative anaerobes like E. coli use aerobic respiration foremost and can switch due to lack of oxygen

question: Explain how fats, and proteins are used as fuel for cellular respiration.

answerLines.raw: Fats: fatty acids are broken down with beta-oxidation, which breaks down fatty acid (glycerol) long —CH tails to use the energy-rich H atoms
answerLines.text: Fats: fatty acids are broken down with beta-oxidation, which breaks down fatty acid (glycerol) long —CH tails to use the energy-rich H atoms

answerLines.raw: Protein: Amino acids can be broken down via deanimation reactions to convert alanine to pyruvate, aspartate to oxaloacetate (to be combined with Acetyl-CoA)
answerLines.text: Protein: Amino acids can be broken down via deanimation reactions to convert alanine to pyruvate, aspartate to oxaloacetate (to be combined with Acetyl-CoA)

question: Explain how plants produce oxygen.

answerLines.raw: Oxygen is a byproduct of the light dependent reaction when water is split (photolysis) for its electrons and H+ gradient. Oxygen is waste.
answerLines.text: Oxygen is a byproduct of the light dependent reaction when water is split (photolysis) for its electrons and H+ gradient. Oxygen is waste.

question: Describe the role of redox reactions in photosynthesis and cellular respiration.

answerLines.raw: Photosynthesis redox reactions:
answerLines.text: Photosynthesis redox reactions:

answerLines.raw: oxidation of water (H2O), which loses electrons to the chlorophyll.
answerLines.text: oxidation of water (H2O), which loses electrons to the chlorophyll.

answerLines.raw: Electrons flow down the ETC in a series of redox reactions, releasing energy used to pump protons and make ATP
answerLines.text: Electrons flow down the ETC in a series of redox reactions, releasing energy used to pump protons and make ATP

answerLines.raw: (Calvin Cycle): The electron carrier NADPH is oxidized (loses electrons) to NADP+
answerLines.text: (Calvin Cycle): The electron carrier NADPH is oxidized (loses electrons) to NADP+

answerLines.raw: Cellular respiration redox reactions:
answerLines.text: Cellular respiration redox reactions:

answerLines.raw: Glycolysis and the Krebs Cycle, dehydrogenases oxidize glucose derivatives, stripping away H atoms and electrons.
answerLines.text: Glycolysis and the Krebs Cycle, dehydrogenases oxidize glucose derivatives, stripping away H atoms and electrons.

answerLines.raw: The stripped electrons are immediately used to reduce NAD+ and FAD into the high-energy carriers NADH and FADH2
answerLines.text: The stripped electrons are immediately used to reduce NAD+ and FAD into the high-energy carriers NADH and FADH2

answerLines.raw: Electron Transport Chain: The carriers are oxidized (they drop off their electrons) at the ETC. The electrons pass down the chain in continuous redox reactions, releasing energy to pump protons.
answerLines.text: Electron Transport Chain: The carriers are oxidized (they drop off their electrons) at the ETC. The electrons pass down the chain in continuous redox reactions, releasing energy to pump protons.

answerLines.raw: Oxygen (O2) acts as the final, highly potent oxidizing agent, gaining the spent electrons and becoming reduced to water (H2O).
answerLines.text: Oxygen (O2) acts as the final, highly potent oxidizing agent, gaining the spent electrons and becoming reduced to water (H2O).

question: Compare photophosphorylation and oxidative phosphorylation.

answerLines.raw: Both use chemiosmosis to generate ATP
answerLines.text: Both use chemiosmosis to generate ATP

answerLines.raw: Both rely on an H+ gradient:
answerLines.text: Both rely on an H+ gradient:

answerLines.raw: For photophosphorylation, it’s located in the thylakoid membrane
answerLines.text: For photophosphorylation, it’s located in the thylakoid membrane

answerLines.raw: For oxidative phosphorylation, it’s located in the mitochondrial intermembrane space
answerLines.text: For oxidative phosphorylation, it’s located in the mitochondrial intermembrane space

answerLines.raw: Photophosphorylation uses electrons from split water to reduce NADP+ to NADPH
answerLines.text: Photophosphorylation uses electrons from split water to reduce NADP+ to NADPH

answerLines.raw: Oxidative Phosphorylation uses electrons from broken down organic molecules to make H2O from oxygen and H+
answerLines.text: Oxidative Phosphorylation uses electrons from broken down organic molecules to make H2O from oxygen and H+

answerLines.raw: Photophosphorylation is like a solar panel (light energy) powering a water pump that creates the energy gradient.
answerLines.text: Photophosphorylation is like a solar panel (light energy) powering a water pump that creates the energy gradient.

answerLines.raw: Oxidative Phosphorylation is like a coal power plant (chemical energy from food) that uses the fuel to power the same water pump.
answerLines.text: Oxidative Phosphorylation is like a coal power plant (chemical energy from food) that uses the fuel to power the same water pump.

question: Describe prokaryotic cell division.

answerLines.raw: Prokaryotes divide by binary fission:
answerLines.text: Prokaryotes divide by binary fission:

question: List and describe the phases of the prokaryotic cell cycle.

answerLines.raw: DNA replication
answerLines.text: DNA replication

answerLines.raw: Cell enlarges, DNA unzips at origin of replication
answerLines.text: Cell enlarges, DNA unzips at origin of replication

answerLines.raw: DNA partitioning
answerLines.text: DNA partitioning

answerLines.raw: Each chromosome attaches to special plasma membrane site
answerLines.text: Each chromosome attaches to special plasma membrane site

answerLines.raw: Cell fission
answerLines.text: Cell fission

answerLines.raw: New plasma membrane, then new cell wall, grows inward
answerLines.text: New plasma membrane, then new cell wall, grows inward

question: Explain how chromosomes are paired and distinguish between homologues and sister chromatids.

answerLines.raw: Homologous chromosomes are 1 from each parent with the same type of information stored in the same location.
answerLines.text: Homologous chromosomes are 1 from each parent with the same type of information stored in the same location.

answerLines.raw: Sister chromatids are the copied versions of each homologue. Each strand is exactly identical, and they are joined at the their centromeres.
answerLines.text: Sister chromatids are the copied versions of each homologue. Each strand is exactly identical, and they are joined at the their centromeres.

question: Draw a nucleosome and discuss its function

answerLines.raw: A complex of 8 histone proteins in a ball with chromatin strands wrapped around it.
answerLines.text: A complex of 8 histone proteins in a ball with chromatin strands wrapped around it.

question: Describe how chromosomes change during interphase

answerLines.raw: DNA replicates and forms 2 identical sister chromatids.
answerLines.text: DNA replicates and forms 2 identical sister chromatids.

question: List the phases of mitosis and describe the events characteristic of each phase.

answerLines.raw: Prophase: nucleolus disappears, condensed chromosomes become visible, centrioles move to opposite ends of the cell and form a network of spindles between them, microtubules extend out and attach to the kinetochore on each side of the chromosomes
answerLines.text: Prophase: nucleolus disappears, condensed chromosomes become visible, centrioles move to opposite ends of the cell and form a network of spindles between them, microtubules extend out and attach to the kinetochore on each side of the chromosomes

answerLines.raw: Metaphase: chromosomes align along equatorial plane, spindle fibers attached to kinetochores extend to opposite ends of the cell
answerLines.text: Metaphase: chromosomes align along equatorial plane, spindle fibers attached to kinetochores extend to opposite ends of the cell

answerLines.raw: Anaphase: chromatids separate, cleaved by enzymes, centromeres rell in microtubules with daughter chromosomes on each end. Each pole now has one set of chromosomes.
answerLines.text: Anaphase: chromatids separate, cleaved by enzymes, centromeres rell in microtubules with daughter chromosomes on each end. Each pole now has one set of chromosomes.

answerLines.raw: Telophase: mitotic spindle disassembled, nuclear envelope forms, chromosomes uncoil, nucleolus reforms
answerLines.text: Telophase: mitotic spindle disassembled, nuclear envelope forms, chromosomes uncoil, nucleolus reforms

question: Distinguish karyokinesis from cytokinesis.

answerLines.raw: Karyokinesis, also known as mitosis, is the M phase of mitosis and precedes cytokinesis.
answerLines.text: Karyokinesis, also known as mitosis, is the M phase of mitosis and precedes cytokinesis.

answerLines.raw: Karyokinesis is the phase in which the in the interior of the cell and its chromosomes are separated toward two opposite poles of the cell
answerLines.text: Karyokinesis is the phase in which the in the interior of the cell and its chromosomes are separated toward two opposite poles of the cell

answerLines.raw: Cytokinesis is the phase in which the cell is cleaved in half
answerLines.text: Cytokinesis is the phase in which the cell is cleaved in half

question: Compare cytokinesis in animal and plant cells.

answerLines.raw: Animal: cleavage furrow is formed by contracting actin microfilaments
answerLines.text: Animal: cleavage furrow is formed by contracting actin microfilaments

answerLines.raw: Plant: Vesicles carrying membrane components form from the center outward. From there, the cell plate grows out.
answerLines.text: Plant: Vesicles carrying membrane components form from the center outward. From there, the cell plate grows out.

question: Locate the three places in the cell cycle where checkpoints occur and describe their action.

answerLines.raw: G1: Cell growth assessed.
answerLines.text: G1: Cell growth assessed.

answerLines.raw: Divide, delay, or rest before S phase?
answerLines.text: Divide, delay, or rest before S phase?

answerLines.raw: Checks environmental conditions
answerLines.text: Checks environmental conditions

answerLines.raw: DNA Damaged?
answerLines.text: DNA Damaged?

answerLines.raw: Materials for replication ready?
answerLines.text: Materials for replication ready?

answerLines.raw: G2: DNA replication assessed
answerLines.text: G2: DNA replication assessed

answerLines.raw: Replicated DNA damaged?
answerLines.text: Replicated DNA damaged?

answerLines.raw: Spindle parts ready?
answerLines.text: Spindle parts ready?

answerLines.raw: M Checkpoint (end of M phase)
answerLines.text: M Checkpoint (end of M phase)

answerLines.raw: Triggers exit from mitosis into cytokinesis
answerLines.text: Triggers exit from mitosis into cytokinesis

answerLines.raw: Spindle fibers attached to chromosomes correctly?
answerLines.text: Spindle fibers attached to chromosomes correctly?

answerLines.raw: Chromosomes aligned and distributed correctly?
answerLines.text: Chromosomes aligned and distributed correctly?

question: Explain how anchorage, cell density, and chemical growth factors control cell division.

answerLines.raw: Cells send out signals to check if they’re anchored to a suitable surface, usually an extracellular matrix, or else they won’t replicate
answerLines.text: Cells send out signals to check if they’re anchored to a suitable surface, usually an extracellular matrix, or else they won’t replicate

answerLines.raw: Cells usually form in a monolayer, limiting their density and stopping division at the G1 phase.
answerLines.text: Cells usually form in a monolayer, limiting their density and stopping division at the G1 phase.

answerLines.raw: Growth factors are external proteins which bind to cell receptors, which activate a chain of events that lead to cell division, getting them past the G1 checkpoint
answerLines.text: Growth factors are external proteins which bind to cell receptors, which activate a chain of events that lead to cell division, getting them past the G1 checkpoint

question: Explain the role of telomeres in limiting cell proliferation.

answerLines.raw: Telomeres start as a region of about 5,000 repeating nucleotides, some of which are lost with every DNA replication. After they are gone, cells enter senescence, and eventually apoptosis
answerLines.text: Telomeres start as a region of about 5,000 repeating nucleotides, some of which are lost with every DNA replication. After they are gone, cells enter senescence, and eventually apoptosis

question: Explain how cancerous cells are different from healthy cells.

answerLines.raw: Cancer is a gene disorder
answerLines.text: Cancer is a gene disorder

answerLines.raw: It is unrestrained cell growth and division caused by damage to genes encoding growth factor, also known as a mutation
answerLines.text: It is unrestrained cell growth and division caused by damage to genes encoding growth factor, also known as a mutation

answerLines.raw: Oncogenes are mutated photo-oncogenes that are overly active and may develop into cancer
answerLines.text: Oncogenes are mutated photo-oncogenes that are overly active and may develop into cancer

question: Explain the link of mutation and the role of p53 in cancer development.

answerLines.raw: P53 is a key regulator of the G1 checkpoint
answerLines.text: P53 is a key regulator of the G1 checkpoint

answerLines.raw: P53 halts cell division if it detects damaged DNA
answerLines.text: P53 halts cell division if it detects damaged DNA

answerLines.raw: If DNA is damaged, it halts cell division and stimulates repair enzymes
answerLines.text: If DNA is damaged, it halts cell division and stimulates repair enzymes

answerLines.raw: If DNA cannot be repaired, p53 directs cell to undergo apoptosis program
answerLines.text: If DNA cannot be repaired, p53 directs cell to undergo apoptosis program

answerLines.raw: P53 is nonfunctional in cancer cells
answerLines.text: P53 is nonfunctional in cancer cells

question: Describe the functions of mitosis and meiosis. Compare mitosis and meiosis, noting similarities and differences.

answerLines.raw: Meiosis II doesn’t replicate chromosomes, resulting in reduction division (number of chromosomes halved
answerLines.text: Meiosis II doesn’t replicate chromosomes, resulting in reduction division (number of chromosomes halved

answerLines.raw: Meiosis results in 4 nonindentical haploid cells, mitosis results in 2 identical diploid cells
answerLines.text: Meiosis results in 4 nonindentical haploid cells, mitosis results in 2 identical diploid cells

answerLines.raw: Meiosis undergoes synapsis and crossover, in which replicated homologous chromosomes pair up and align, and exchange sections of chromosomes
answerLines.text: Meiosis undergoes synapsis and crossover, in which replicated homologous chromosomes pair up and align, and exchange sections of chromosomes

question: Distinguish between gametes and zygotes, between diploid cells and haploid cells, and asexual from sexual reproduction.

answerLines.raw: Gametes are the haploid product of diploid germ-line cells
answerLines.text: Gametes are the haploid product of diploid germ-line cells

answerLines.raw: Zygotes are form from the coming together of two gametes
answerLines.text: Zygotes are form from the coming together of two gametes

answerLines.raw: Diploid = 2 of each chromosome type (2n)
answerLines.text: Diploid = 2 of each chromosome type (2n)

answerLines.raw: Haploid = 1 set of chromosomes (n)
answerLines.text: Haploid = 1 set of chromosomes (n)

answerLines.raw: Asexual reproduction does not involve meiosis
answerLines.text: Asexual reproduction does not involve meiosis

question: Explain why sexual reproduction requires meiosis.

answerLines.raw: Sexual reproduction must result in the same number of chromosomes as each parent. Reduction division halves the number of chromosomes for gamete so that, when combined into a zygote, the chromosome total is the same as the parents
answerLines.text: Sexual reproduction must result in the same number of chromosomes as each parent. Reduction division halves the number of chromosomes for gamete so that, when combined into a zygote, the chromosome total is the same as the parents

question: Compare the life cycles of protists, animals and plants.
Distinguish between germ-line and somatic cells.

answerLines.raw: Germ-line cells undergo meiosis to produce gametes
answerLines.text: Germ-line cells undergo meiosis to produce gametes

answerLines.raw: Somatic cells undergo mitosis to make identical cells
answerLines.text: Somatic cells undergo mitosis to make identical cells

question: List the four stages of meiosis I

answerLines.raw: Prophase I: homologous chromosomes pair up. During synapsis, crossing over occurs in which nonsister chromatids exchange portions of DNA strands
answerLines.text: Prophase I: homologous chromosomes pair up. During synapsis, crossing over occurs in which nonsister chromatids exchange portions of DNA strands

answerLines.raw: Metaphase I: homologues held by crossovers, spindles can only attach to outward-facing kinetochore of centromere (random)
answerLines.text: Metaphase I: homologues held by crossovers, spindles can only attach to outward-facing kinetochore of centromere (random)

answerLines.raw: Independent assortment: different orientations of chromosomes = gametes with different combinations of parental chromosomes
answerLines.text: Independent assortment: different orientations of chromosomes = gametes with different combinations of parental chromosomes

answerLines.raw: Anaphase I: homologues pulled apart to opposite poles
answerLines.text: Anaphase I: homologues pulled apart to opposite poles

answerLines.raw: Each pole has half the number of chromosomes than the start
answerLines.text: Each pole has half the number of chromosomes than the start

answerLines.raw: Telophase I: chromosomes gather to form 2 clusters
answerLines.text: Telophase I: chromosomes gather to form 2 clusters

question: State how many copies of each chromosome are present at the end of meiosis II.

answerLines.raw: 1 copy of each chromosome
answerLines.text: 1 copy of each chromosome

question: Describe the process of crossing over, identifying when it occurs and the elements involved.

answerLines.raw: Crossing over happens during meiosis I, at the prophase stage. Nonsister chromatids exchange DNA
answerLines.text: Crossing over happens during meiosis I, at the prophase stage. Nonsister chromatids exchange DNA

question: Define synapsis.

answerLines.raw: When homologous chromosomes physically align and pair up so that crossover can occur.
answerLines.text: When homologous chromosomes physically align and pair up so that crossover can occur.

question: Explain why meiosis results in a reduction division.

answerLines.raw: Because it goes through two rounds of division, and during the second, chromosomes are not copied
answerLines.text: Because it goes through two rounds of division, and during the second, chromosomes are not copied

question: Explain the three principal mechanisms whereby genetic variation is produced in sexually reproducing organisms.

answerLines.raw: Crossing over
answerLines.text: Crossing over

answerLines.raw: Independent assortment
answerLines.text: Independent assortment

answerLines.raw: Random fertilization
answerLines.text: Random fertilization

question: Explain the role of sex in generating evolutionary novelty.

answerLines.raw: Gametes alone have over 8 million possible combinations of DNA
answerLines.text: Gametes alone have over 8 million possible combinations of DNA

answerLines.raw: But with random fertilization, the possible outcomes are 70 trillion
answerLines.text: But with random fertilization, the possible outcomes are 70 trillion
